content.rendered:
All I can think of is the wonderful Monty Python sketch..Spam Spam Spam Spam….
Have I ever even tasted the stuff? Not on a dare.

excerpt.rendered: All I can think of is the wonderful Monty Python sketch..Spam Spam Spam Spam….Have I ever even tasted the stuff? Not on a dare.

content.rendered: I have to admit, as a Yonsei born and raised in Hawaiʻi, I thought Spam was specifically a Hawaiʻi thing. We proudly ate it breakfast, lunch and dinner, and the spam musubi was a no-brainer for days at the beach or when you didn’t have time to make lunch for your kids (but you only go to certain grocery stores that made the most “ono” ones – gadda be Koloaʻs Sueoka store). If you found out a kid – or adult – didn’t like spam, they were considered weird. Odd. Why do you live here if you donʻt like Spam? Hawaiʻi…Spam…itʻs synonymous. Duh. It is so pervasive, we have Spam Jams where 25,000 people gather to try spam ice cream (I heard it was good!), spam pizza, spam candy bar, and spam nachos. Itʻs even on the menu at McDonalds, for Godʻs sake. As per the Smithsonian article on Spam, we can conversely blame and thank the military for spreading the joy of spam. But more importantly for us here in Hawaiʻi, tiny dots in the middle of the Pacific, it is spam and toilet paper you hoard when there is a hurricane or Matson strike. Cases of those 2 things and I can make it for months. Happy. Spam is a menu staple of island cuisine, a lifesaver during emergencies, a form of behavioral bribery for your children, and personally, for me, a way to love and remember the most awesome, smart, ditzy dad in the world. Part of his ashes are hidden away in a ʻsecretʻ special place, sealed with duck tape in a spam can. The only meal he ever made for me and my sisters. Ever. Spam.

excerpt.rendered: I have to admit, as a Yonsei born and raised in Hawaiʻi, I thought Spam was specifically a Hawaiʻi thing. We proudly ate it breakfast, lunch and dinner, and the spam musubi was a no-brainer for days at the beach or when you didn’t have time to make lunch for your kids (but you only … Continue reading Kat From Kauaʻi →

content.rendered: My family loves to use SPAM in many dishes. We eat it in Kimchi stew, Kimchi Fried rice, we would even just fry it on the side and eat it with eggs and rice. Since I was a little kid, I would always look forward to eating SPAM. I would eat it for breakfast with rice, I would eat it for lunch in some kimbap, and I would have it for dinner in a stew or with fried rice. And if it had some Pork instead, I would probably complain about not having SPAM. SPAM was always a tasty treat that made me feel good. It was oily, meaty, juicy, and contained a crucial part of almost every meal I ate.

title.rendered: 6/24 Specially Processed American Me – Film Screening & Talkback

content.rendered:
Flushing Town Hall will host a community screening of Jaime Sunwoo’s theatrical production Specially Processed American Me on Saturday June 24, the day before the anniversary of the start of the Korean war. The event will include a talkback to reflect on the ongoing Korean War and how war impacts Asian American communities today, using themes from the film as a starting point. Spam dishes from local Korean restaurants will be served.

Specially Processed American Me by Jaime Sunwoo is a surreal autobiographical performance using SPAM, the canned meat, as a portal into her Asian American upbringing and her family’s experiences of the Korean War. It investigates SPAM’s legacy in the military and its significance across the Asia-Pacific– Korea, the Philippines, Okinawa, Hawaii, and Guam. The film will be subtitled in Korean to make it accessible to Korean speaking audiences.

Flushing Town Hall 137-35 Northern Blvd, Queens, NY 11354

S﻿aturday June 24, 1-4pm

12:30pm doors open

1pm show starts.

Spam dishes from local Korean restaurants will be served after the talkback.

DONATION

Donations can be made directly via Venmo to @FreeRein-Projects or by check payable to ‘Free Rein Projects’ at 1 Main Street #7E, Brooklyn, NY 11201.

To make a tax-deductible donation, please consider making a contribution to Leviathan Lab at leviathanlab.org/supportleviathanlab and under ‘Additional Information’ include ‘Free Rein Projects’, or by check or money order payable to ‘Leviathan Lab’ and earmarked in the memo line to ‘Free Rein Projects’.

Free Rein Projects is a member of the fiscally sponsored artist program at Leviathan Lab, a nonprofit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) arts organization by and for NYC-based Asian American Native Hawaiian Pacific Islander (AANHPI) theatre and film artists. Contributions made are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

The filmed theatrical production of Specially Processed American Me was produced by Free Rein Projects and made with support from Asian Women Giving Circle. Event sponsors include Korean American Family Service Center, The Korea Society, WomanKind, The Association of Asian American Yale Alumni, Leviathan Lab, Coalition for Asian American Children and Families, REACH Coalition, and our space sponsor Flushing Town Hall.

content.rendered:
The Self Evident team joined us during our residency at BRIC, observed our rehearsals, and chatted with Jaime Sunwoo and her father to unpack Specially Processed American Me. Listen to the episode here.

About the episode:

Korean American playwright Jaime Sunwoo’s surreal new play, Specially Processed American Me, takes a close look at Spam’s legacies, and the lost stories of her own family — who’ve migrated twice over two generations, from North Korean to South Korea, then from South Korea to the United States.

While sharing behind-the-scenes previews of the play, Jaime and Cathy talk about the challenges and rewards of interviewing older generations, and how those conversations have helped her process her own identity as an Asian American.

content.rendered:
When people ask me if people actually like Spam in Korea or what value Spam holds in Korean culture, I always tell them this story. Even to this date, my friends and family often give and receive gift sets of Spam on holidays like Chuseok and Lunar New Year. It’s a common gift option especially by corporations to their employees, and I haven’t met someone that outspokenly complained about receiving a gift set of Spam.

Spam goes well with anything honestly, but one of my family recipes is making a Korean-style toast with cabbage, eggs, and two thin slices of spam. There is something about Spam that hits you differently than sliced ham does.

Even to this date, my friends and family often give and receive gift sets of Spam on holidays like Chuseok and Lunar New Year. It’s a common gift option especially … Continue reading Sally →

content.rendered: I was born and raised in California but most of my dad’s side of the family is from Oahu. Spam and eggs, spam musubi have always been comfort foods for me. Most of my friends growing up were 1st or 2nd generation Asian-American and I felt that the foods that I had when we visited family every year were the closest to me. I’ve introduced it to people in college, to mixed reactions. I went vegetarian for a couple years and that was one of the foods I missed.

Most of my friends growing up were 1st or 2nd generation Asian-American and I felt that the foods that I had when we visited … Continue reading Mika →

content.rendered:
THE DHARMA OF SPAM

Churches and food seem to go hand in hand in America. Lutheran church picnics are famous for their potato salad; the Methodists, they say, love their coffee and donuts; a Mormon potluck wouldn’t be complete without pretzel-jello salad; and pretty much every religious gathering welcomes a good bundt cake. I’m here to inform you that none of these religions has got anything on Buddhism, food-wise. I’m not talking about just any Buddhism, by the way—I’m talking about good old, red-blooded, BCA Buddhism. BCA stands for “Buddhist Churches of America,” and the coal that stokes the engine of the BCA membership is a savory delight called Spam musubi.

BCA Buddhism is so American it has the word “church” right in its title (even though all of us call it “temple”). It’s so American it features Sunday morning services with polished wooden pews, a minister (sensei), a sermon (Dharma talk), and an organist playing hymns (gathas). The temple I attended for years is a typical example. After service, there was choir practice and coffee (and green tea) for the adults, and the kids ran off to Dharma school, where they memorized the Five Precepts and the Eightfold Path (our corollaries to the Ten Commandments).

And, just like at every other church in America, Buddhist temple festivals revolve around food. In winter, there’s the Mochitsuki, where volunteers cook huge vats of sticky rice, which the strong and able-bodied men and boys then pound with massive wooden mallets until all the grains of rice become one. This glutinous mass of oobleck is then dusted with rice flour, divided into belly busting balls of pure carbohydrate (mochi), and served with shoyu and sugar, or in hot salty broth, where it oozes like a lava lamp.

Come summer, there’s Obon, the foodiest festival of the year. That’s when all the temples swing into high gear and start making food in immeasurable quantities—enough to feed the whole neighborhood for days. “Secret recipe” chicken teriyaki grills continuously, filling the air with sweet soy and ginger smoke. Sushi and soba and Shiz’s special salmon round out the lighter fare. But it’s the Spam musubi that powers the taiko drummers and keeps the kids and teens coming back for more.

Spam: the official red (pink?) meat of the Aloha State. Slice it into slabs (and not just any slabs—you’ve got to use the official Spam slicer to get that uniform shape), simmer them in teriyaki sauce, then press each slice between two layers of sticky rice and wrap the whole thing in seaweed (nori). What you end up with is a brick—a dense, heavy, salty, chewy brick of Buddhist goodness. There’s no explaining why it’s so good. It just is.

In preparation for Obon, volunteers work for hours in the temple kitchen, making trays and trays of Spam musubis the size of driveway pavers. Spam musubi is so integral to the temple that the Dharma school students learn about the Buddhist principal of interdependence by making the stuff in teams—the musubi maker blind-folded while his teammates shout instructions. Everyone eats the messy results.

I have fond memories of going to temple. I loved the weekly reminders to be mindful in my actions and to avoid grasping for outcomes that were beyond my control. I loved the smell of the incense that lingered in my hair for the rest of the day. I loved the Dharma talks by our wise, gentle, funny sensei, and the chanting of the Juseige (GA GON CHO SE GAN, HIS-SHI MU JO DO…). I miss sitting amongst the sangha (congregation), a sea of older Japanese Americans who could be my aunts and uncles. I miss their hapa kids and grandkids, with their blond hair and almond eyes.

Like so many organizations that run on volunteer efforts, my temple had its committee chairs (mostly older women, whom I referred to as “the church ladies”), who took it upon themselves to round up volunteers. Congregants fell into roughly three categories: There were the die-hard do-ers who threw themselves into every task with limitless energy and high spirits; trailing behind them were the unenthusiastic semi-commitment types, of which I’d include myself; at the bottom of the pile were the out-and-out avoiders, people who had said no so many times that no one bothered to ask them any more.

For a while there, I loved standing at the long work stations making mochi or an pan (sweet bean paste buns), listening in on the temple gossip buzzing around me. But because I’d said yes a few times, I kept getting asked to do more. After a while, I started to chafe. I wanted to actually celebrate Obon, not spend it working in the kitchen. Some Sundays, I just wanted to meditate and breathe and go home, not stick around to help the Lotus class with arts and crafts.

The trouble is, it’s really hard to say no when a stern looking baachan (grandma) with a clipboard asks you to take on an extra shift at the Spam musubi station—really, really hard. I’m ashamed to admit that there were times I’d see one of the church ladies after service and literally duck to hide myself behind the crowd at the snack table. Finally, I started sleeping in on Sundays, telling myself I’d go next week. It’s been over two years.

Maybe I’ll get back there one day. I still think of it as “my” temple. At my temple, the incense is sweet and we chant the Loving-kindness meditation in unison. At my temple, we line up after service to shake the sensei’s hand and he jokes and talks briefly with each and every one of us. At my temple, the volunteers work overtime, and the Eightfold Path is paved with Spam musubi.

I’m here … Continue reading Laura Westley →

content.rendered: My Canadian family grew up on spam. Mum used to do it in the oven (I believe) with an outer layer of brown sugar. Seem to recall we also ate it with mustard. Bringing back good memories – must try it again!

excerpt.rendered: My Canadian family grew up on spam. Mum used to do it in the oven (I believe) with an outer layer of brown sugar. Seem to recall we also ate it with mustard. Bringing back good memories – must try it again!

content.rendered: My Mom must of learned about Spam when we lived in Hawaii. My Stepdad was stationed there. I don’t recall having it though until we moved back to the State’s. Mom made sweet and sour spam that was so good. She also made stir fry. I loved Spam and eggs, fried spam on white bread and Spam cut up and added to box Mac and cheese. It’s been a long time since I’ve had Spam but sure loved it growing up.

content.rendered: Spam has always been an integral part of gimbap dinners, when my mom wraps up rice, spam, egg, and spinach inside a sheet of seaweed, using a bamboo mat to roll it up tight and setting it aside to slice later. One of my fondest childhood memories is of stealing crispy strips of spam before they could go into the gimbap (and occasionally having my hand smacked for it!)

content.rendered:
It was a pleasure to chat with Eric Kim about Specially Processed American Me. In this thoughtful piece for Food52, Eric reflects on SPAM with Asian American artists, writers, and chefs including Lucas Sin, who made a delicious SPAM meal at our workshop at the Museum of Food and Drink. Read the article here.

…Spam has a completely different reputation in your parents’ home country than it does in the States, and that, as an Asian American, it has the ability to transport you home wherever you are in the world. As Sunwoo said, “The reason we gravitate toward Spam so strongly is because we only eat it at home.” Home food is inherently more intimate, more private, and thus has more potential to be intricately riddled with secrecy, even shame.

Eric Kim, Food 52

content.rendered: When I was a teenager, I spent summers in the Midwest with my dad and his family following my parents’ divorce. As an only child far from her primary home in New Orleans and with my dad working full-time, things could sometimes get a bit dull. I always had the TV and plenty of books to keep me company, but these were the early days of the Internet, and so there weren’t the multitudes of solo outlets to keep oneself busy for long stretches of time. Yet, somehow, even in those young days of the Internet circa 2003 or so, I managed to stumble across information for the Hormel SPAM museum in Austin, MN. Only a two hour drive from my dad’s house, I convinced him he had to take the day off and take me there. Now, I was largely unexposed to SPAM at this point in my life beyond the famous Monty Python sketch and jokes about mystery meat – while I was no stranger to canned and processed foods, having a robust stock of them in our hurricane preparedness kit at home in Louisiana (including Vienna Sausages and literal “potted meat”), I had never once tasted SPAM or knew anyone who had. The museum was meant to be a giant gag, an inside joke to share with my dad. Now almost 20 years later, however, I look back on that visit to the SPAM museum with such fondness. Not only was the museum incredible – extremely well curated and with a full-scale reproduction of the Monty Python set – but the time I spent there and on the road trip with my dad was one of our most fun father-daughter bonding times of my childhood. It was also my first introduction to SPAM itself – and I immediately fell in love. We bought all sorts of speciality flavors from the gift shop and took them home to try new dishes using SPAM. I returned home to New Orleans at the end of summer and convinced my mom to add this to our hurricane kit – and make me the periodic fried SPAM sandwich (with mustard). Throughout my adult life, I’ve never not had SPAM in my pantry and, like a lot of other adults (especially in the San Francisco Bay Area where I now live), SPAM was one of the primary foods I stocked up on at the beginning of the COVID pandemic. Today, SPAM plays an important culinary role in my and my fiancé’s life – we routinely fry up half a block and add it to our various flavors of instant ramen. In my spicy Korean ramen picks, the SPAM adds a sweetness to balance the spice. In my fiancé’s simpler soy ramens, the [low-sodium] SPAM adds an extra kick of salt and umami. SPAM also makes for an easy, weeknight fried rice solution – with eggs, green onion, soy sauce, rice and SPAM you have a very complete meal, and even better if you can add-in some frozen / defrosted shrimp to balance the saltier flavors. To this day, I credit that fateful trip to the SPAM museum as being one of the most memorable and pivotal culinary moments in my life.

content.rendered:
Basic recipe for spam musubi

Pan fry spam crisp/charred
Yoshida sauce until carmelized
Nore… Rice… Spam… Rice… Wrap
Always oiishi 🤙

Spam musubi has been a staple at every major family event since I can remember. Growing up JA, you never thought twice about why we enjoyed spam like we did.

Reflection allows us to step back and remember where we came from and why we are who we are.

My grandma was born in manzanar and so this always hits home. But nevertheless, spam musubi has and always will be tied to good times.

No matter breakfast/lunch/dinner, time of the year, event/holiday, or even what’s being served (spaghetti and spam)… Nobody in this ohana says no to spam musubi

Growing up JA, you never thought twice about why we enjoyed spam like we did. Reflection allows us to step back and … Continue reading David N →

content.rendered:
When I was married and cooked for a family of 6, money was scarce, so a regular Mid-western dinner was baking a baked beans & Spam casserole. Super economical to buy the ingredients and mix together in a casserole dish and bake.

Bush’s Baked Beans, with maple syrup or brown sugar style (1-2 large cans)
Spam – original or Teriyaki style (1 can)
1/2 large onion- diced
Minced garlic (optional)
Shredded cheddar cheese
spices to taste

Empty baked beans into oven-proof casserole dish or rectangle pan.
Slice Spam into 6 thin slices and set aside.
Cube remaining Spam and mix into the beans.
Dice onion and mix into the beans.
Add minced garlic (optional).
Sprinkle with any spices you prefer.
Mix together well and flatten top of beans mixture.
Lay the thin slices of Spam as casserole topper.
Cover with a layer of shredded cheddar cheese.

Bake 350 degrees, center rack, for 30 minutes.

I suppose I topped the casserole with 6 slices of Spam because I had 6 people to feed, so everyone at the table got one crispy baked and cheesy slice of Spam, along with a full serving of hot, sweetened baked beans, with chunks of Spam and onions.

I always made this dinner at home, but it could be enjoyed at a BBQ picnic as a side dish or at a cookout/camping trip.

Everyone likes beans and wieners–I love Spam and beans!

excerpt.rendered: When I was married and cooked for a family of 6, money was scarce, so a regular Mid-western dinner was baking a baked beans & Spam casserole. Super economical to buy the ingredients and mix together in a casserole dish and bake. Bush’s Baked Beans, with maple syrup or brown sugar style (1-2 large cans)Spam … Continue reading Ann – From Ohio (now living in Hawaii) →

content.rendered: I am an American Anglo and my story goes back to my childhood in the 60’s. We were into camping spring through fall. Our “home” was 9×9 green canvas tent. My mind goes back to those days whenever I happen upon such canvas. Spam was breakfast fare, along with sliced potatoes, both fried golden brown with crispy edges. Scrambled eggs eggs were there in a fluffy yellow mound. A puddle of ketchup might be there too. It tastes great on the Spam and the potatoes, especially to a kid. Just writing about it brings back visions of the heavily varnished picnic table made with thick cut planks of pine with its rich red brown knots. The clean fresh air scented with wood smoke and maybe bacon from your neighbors breakfast pan.

excerpt.rendered: I am an American Anglo and my story goes back to my childhood in the 60’s. We were into camping spring through fall. Our “home” was 9×9 green canvas tent. My mind goes back to those days whenever I happen upon such canvas. Spam was breakfast fare, along with sliced potatoes, both fried golden brown … Continue reading Rodney →

content.rendered: When I was a child and one of four, we were poor. Our mother served Spam often (as well as tongue and other less savory items). But she always served it cold, and that layer of jelly was unpleasant. It wasn’t until I was in my 40s that I discovered Spam could be cooked, and that it was delicious, especially with egg over easy or scrambled. I had never thought of buying it as an adult because of those nasty childhood memories. The meat was good, of course, but heating it up is much better, whether served on as plate or in a sandwich. I think I will go and buy some more today, just thinking about it makes me hungry.

excerpt.rendered: When I was a child and one of four, we were poor. Our mother served Spam often (as well as tongue and other less savory items). But she always served it cold, and that layer of jelly was unpleasant. It wasn’t until I was in my 40s that I discovered Spam could be cooked, and … Continue reading Miuchael T →

content.rendered: I bought SPAM for our food storage last year. Wildfires, a pandemic, political uncertainty made me feel good seeing it on the shelf with canned veggies, fruit, dried eggs and stored water. But as I looked at it ever day, I realized I have to rotate this food, not just look at with the satisfaction of having it but not eating it. So, on Saturday, I opened up one of the cans on a bottom shelf, sliced it up with some scrambled eggs and cheese, and chowed down with some wheat toast and coffee. It was delicious. I don’t have the shame of eating SPAM in private, though I understand why people consider it poor people food. I don’t, though.

excerpt.rendered: I bought SPAM for our food storage last year. But as I looked at it ever day, I realized I have to rotate this food, not just look at with the satisfaction … Continue reading Don in Portland, OR →

content.rendered:
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 8:00 – 9:30PM EDT

Queens Council on the Arts’ Artist Commissioning Program (ACP) and Flushing Town Hall present a play reading and talkback of Jaime Sunwoo’s Specially Processed American Me. This event is free and open to the public. Registered attendees will receive an email with the watch link. RSVP is required:
RSVP here
This piece was commissioned by seven Flushing-affiliated art community members, or art commissioners who selected the project and advised the artist throughout its development.
ART COMMISSIONERS: BRANKA DUKNIC, CLAIRE MARIE LIM, EMILY GROSS, JAMERRY KIM, JEFFERSON MAO, JOHN CHOE, YA YUN TENG
ADVISORY PANELISTS: ROB URBINATI, SEGJIN PARK, SOH YOUNG LEE-SEGREDO

ABOUT THE ARTIST COMMISSIONING PROGRAM
Queens Council on the Arts (QCA)’s Artist Commissioning Program (ACP) democratizes the traditional commissioning process, which has historically been reserved for a privileged few. The program enables local community members, or “Art Commissioners” to fill gaps in American culture by awarding $10,000 commissions to choreographers, playwrights, and composers that tell untold stories highlighting underrepresented protagonists. Every year, the ACP focuses on two Queens neighborhoods: the 2019-2020 cycle highlights the communities of Flushing and Maspeth/Ridgewood. By commissioning artists to materials works resonate with these communities, the ACP aims to create a cultural sector more reflective of the diversity of Queens and the nation.

ABOUT FLUSHING TOWN HALL
Flushing Town Hall (FTH), a Smithsonian affiliate, presents multi-disciplinary global arts that engage and educate the global communities of Queens and New York City, in order to foster mutual appreciation. As advocates of arts equity since 1979, we support local, immigrant, national, and international artists, developing partnerships and collaborations that enhance our efforts. As a member of New York City’s Cultural Institutions Group (CIG), we serve to restore, manage and program the historic 1862 landmark on behalf of the City of New York. FTH celebrates the history of Queens as the home of Jazz, by presenting the finest in Jazz performance. We are committed to arts education and hands-on learning, for the arts-curious, arts enthusiasts, and professional artists. We serve one of the most diverse communities in the world, and strive to uphold the legacy of inclusiveness that has defined our community since the Flushing Remonstrance of 1657.

title.rendered: 8/6 ACP Live: Reflecting on the 70th anniversary of the Korean War

content.rendered:
Queens Council on the Arts’ Artist Commissioning Program (ACP) and Flushing Town Hall are pleased to present ACP Live – a work in progress showcase and discussion of Jaime Sunwoo’s Specially Processed American Me, a new surreal autobiographical performance selected by Flushing art commissioners.
In honor of the 70th anniversary of the Korean War, ACP Art Commissioner and moderator Sejin Park will lead a panel discussion with questions inspired by the themes Sunwoo explores in her play– family, identity, immigration, and war trauma– as an opportunity to reflect on how the war has shaped the Korean American community. We welcome people of all ages to join the conversation. The event will include Korean subtitles.
This is a free event with a suggested donation. All proceeds will be donated to Queens Council on the Arts and Korean American Family Service Center.
PANELISTS
– Jaime Sunwoo, ACP Awardee in Playwriting
– Sejin Park (moderator), Flushing Art Commissioner & Education Coordinator, The Noguchi Museum
– John Choe, Flushing Art Commissioner & Executive Director, Greater Flushing Chamber of Commerce
– Jeehae Fischer, Executive Director, Korean American Family Service Center
– HJ Lee, Co-Founder & Executive Director, KoreanAmericanStory.org
-Heejeong Sohn, Senior Lecturer and Assistant Director, Center for Korean Studies, Stony Brook University
Stream it LIVE on QCA’s Youtube or FTH’s Facebook Page!

THURSDAY, AUGUST 6, 7:00PM – 8:00PM
RSVP here to receive the watch link.

In honor of the 70th anniversary of the Korean War, ACP … Continue reading 8/6 ACP Live: Reflecting on the 70th anniversary of the Korean War →

The NYC Women’s Fund for Media, Music and Theatre provides grants to encourage and support the creation of digital, film, music, television, and live theatre content that reflects the voices and perspectives of all who identify as women.

See a list of all the awardees and learn more about the NYC Womens Fund here.

title.rendered: 2/27 We’ll be at the Museum of Food and Drink!

content.rendered:
Join playwright and artist Jaime Sunwoo for an interactive discussion about the history of SPAM, the canned meat, in the Asia-Pacific and its connection to war, class, and nostalgia. Sunwoo will share her process of creating her multidisciplinary performance project, Specially Processed American Me, and reveal why she uses SPAM as a metaphor for the Asian American experience. Attendees will get a sneak peek of her upcoming show, share reflections on SPAM, and get a taste of a special SPAM dishes created by chef Lucas Sin of Junzi Kitchen and chef Sehyun Hong of Gentle Perch.
Date: Thursday February 27, 7-9pm
Location: Museum of Food and Drink (Williamsburg): 62 Bayard St, Brooklyn, NY 11222
Event Links: Tickets ; FB Event

content.rendered:
A reading of SPECIALLY PROCESSED AMERICAN ME by Jaime Sunwoo
Saturday & Sunday, December 14 & 15 | 7pm
120 Bank Street, New York – First Floor Studio
Free with RSVP: https://tinyurl.com/wqdcgxj

Join us for a reading of Jaime Sunwoo’s Specially Processed American Me, a surreal autobiographical performance using SPAM, the canned meat, as a portal into her Asian American upbringing and her family’s experiences of the Korean War. Oscillating wildly between absurd humor and sober tragedy, genuine affection and biting criticism, ‘Specially Processed American Me’ is a thought-provoking exploration of one of America’s most misunderstood foods.

Presented as part of HB Studio Residency 2019.

Past development support thanks to Leviathan Lab, Barn Arts, FailSafe Festival NYC

Performed by Jaime Sunwoo, Juella Baltonado, Nathaniel Basch-Gould, Adrianna Mateo, Arielle Rabano.
Music and Lyrics by Matt Chilton.
Dramaturgy by Alex M. Lee.

content.rendered: I never really liked spam, but it was a staple growing up in Saipan. We grew up with very little so we ate what was on the table – or in my case, went to bed hungry or saved up to sneak other food of our own. When we did have spam, I liked it best when my mum made it thin and crispy. I didn’t care much for it otherwise, but after I moved to Hawai’i my college roommates exposed me to all the wondrous snacks that could be had around town, including 7-11 spam musubis. It took me several years living in LA after that to really appreciate and miss the yummy goodness of spam – whether it be in musubi, fried rice, with eggs/Portuguese sausage/rice in a Hawai’i McDonald’s breakfast deluxe platter or in saimin.. I make a point to get spam musubis at friend gatherings, luaus and Hawaiian joints now, but I still have only bought it a grand total of one time since I left home at 18 and even then it took me forever to crack it open. I love the mini musubis, they’re the perfect size for me. SPAM is such an integral part of island life. I went home for the first time in 10 years by way of the Philippines and was left in awe at the abundance of access to fresh, cheap, healthy food out here on the US mainland. In Saipan and in the Philippines, fresh food and less perishable products are, in stark contrast, pretty consistently separate, and the effects of colonization are easily evident. As a child we learned that SPAM stood for Salt, Pork and Ham (clearly debatable and variable today), and that it was originally used by soldiers rationing goods during the war, hence how salty it was. This pattern of preserved foods is true of many dishes in our mixed culture, and I always feel like I’ve stepped in a time warp into the Old World whenever I visit home. Being a lower-class first-generation Filipino American born to two provincial immigrant parents, I am surprised at the depth of grit my family was able to reach in order to survive Saipan. To know one world and understand it through the lens of the other is an indescribably humbling feeling. Understanding and connecting one another through foods like spam reminds me that I am fortunate to have made it to the other side of America. It both saddens me and gives me great pride to be the bridge between two such drastically different worlds. Most of all, it’s amazing the stories such simple everyday artifacts as food can bring.

excerpt.rendered: I never really liked spam, but it was a staple growing up in Saipan. We grew up with very little so we ate what was on the table – or in my case, went to bed hungry or saved up to sneak other food of our own. When we did have spam, I liked it … Continue reading Jayce Jurado →

content.rendered:
We’re sharing sculptures, video, and collected stories from Specially Processed American Me at Flux Factory!

Curated by Abdul Dube, Illesha Khandelwal and Will Owen, Wicket Leeks uses the lenses of food and sports to showcase cooks, athletes, researchers, artists, coaches, and makers to help investigate the unsavory histories of nationalist, religious, and corporate colonialism in a palatable way, while not sugar-coating its effects, in order to help us better digest our present and cook up a healthier future.

The title Wicket Leeks refers to the wicket– a part of the equipment for the sport of Cricket spread by the British Empire, and Leeks– one of the most common and ancient edible plants in the onion family. It is also in reference to WikiLeaks– the international investigative journalism non-profit.

Featured Artists: Anna Andrzhievskaia, Epicurean Endocrinology (Liz Flyntz & Byron Rich), Fay Sanders, Hande Sever, Janine Georgette (Hamilton), Jaime Sunwoo, Jevijoe Vitug, Jordany Geao, Dr. Joshua D. Phillips, Jess Rolls, Julian Louis Phillips, Kacie Lyn Martinez, Lexy Ho-Tai, Miss Expanding Universe (Ashley Yang-Thompson), Nathaniel Sullivan, Nick Whittock, Shane Farrell, Sneha Mehta & Mallika Chandra, Zaid Islam

Full schedule here.

JUNE 22-JULY 13
Wicket Leeks Exhibition at Flux Factory
39-31 29th Street Long Island City, NY 11101
Exhibition Hours: Thursday-Sunday 1-6pm
Opening Reception: June 22nd, 6-10pm

title.rendered: 5/22-6/21 Beyond Boundaries Exhibition at Korean Cultural Center NY

content.rendered:
May 22-June 21, Korean Cultural Center NY will display sculptures, videos, and community stories collected by Jaime Sunwoo for Specially Processed American Me as part of the Beyond Boundaries exhibition. The exhibition will present works of selected artists whose practices range across diverse mediums and go beyond traditional artistic boundaries. This group show of 9 artists introduces a large number of experimental works of different genres, including installation, painting, illustration, video, and sculpture. Curator Hee Sung Cho at the Korean Cultural Center New York remarked, “As artists who view the world through a delicate and sensitive perspective, and as individuals who are living in this complicated and fast-changing contemporary society, the artists show how they each experience today’s dynamic world. This show hopes to allow the viewers to discover and identify with their new, exciting viewpoints.”

Artists: Jihyun Hong, Nayoung Jeong, Jong Sook Kang, Bonam Kim, Kieum Kim, Genevieve Quick, Gene Kim, Jeongwon Yoon, Jaime Sunwoo.

Beyond Boundaries
May 22nd, 2019 – June 21st, 2019
Opening: May 22nd, 6 PM – 8 PM

Gallery Korea of the Korean Cultural Center New York
460 Park Ave., 6th Fl., NYC
Gallery Hours: 9 AM – 5 PM, Mon-Fri

content.rendered:
We’ll be performing at The Tank! We’ve developed new scenes with Leviathan Lab and
are excited to show how much this project has evolved. Join us!

SUN May 12, 3pm
MON May 13, 7pm
WED May 15, 7pm
The Tank (312 W 36th st, New York, NY)
$18 General Admission | Get Tickets

Specially Processed American Me by Jaime Sunwoo is a multidisciplinary performance using SPAM, the canned meat, to share memories of her Korean American upbringing and her family’s accounts of the Korean War. It investigates SPAM’s legacy in the military, its significance in the Asia-Pacific, and its influence on Asian cuisine through a narrative collage of monologues, animation, soundscapes, sculpture, and cooking. Thrashing between absurd humor and sober tragedy, genuine affection and biting criticism, Specially Processed American Me is a thought-provoking exploration of one of America’s most misunderstood foods. In addition to performances, Specially Processed American Me holds food history and storytelling workshops over a communal SPAM meal. To learn more, follow @speciallyprocessed on Facebook and Instagram.

title.rendered: 4/8 SPAM, War, and Cuisine Workshop at NYU

content.rendered:
Jaime Sunwoo will lead a community workshop on April 8th with NYU Asian American Political Activism Coalition – NYU APAC. Learn about the history of SPAM in the Asia-Pacific and how it relates to her performance project Specially Processed American Me. Attendees are welcome to contribute a SPAM-based dish for the potluck.

Monday, April 8th 6-8pm
Kimmel 405 at NYU
Free and open to the public with RSVP.

NYU APAC is a student-led coalition with the mission to politically educate and mobilize Asian American and Asian diaspora students at NYU for our collective liberation. We use the term “Asian American” not to refer to US citizenship or papers, but to the political project and ongoing struggle of Asian America. We recognize “Asian American” as a pan-ethnic political coalition that emerged from the Asian American Movement in the 1960s and 1970s. We place intersectionality at our core, aiming to build solidarity between the diverse Asian diasporas in the United States as well as the marginalized communities in and out of our coalition.

title.rendered: 3/6 Join us for a lecture at the Charles B Wang Center at Stony Brook University

content.rendered:
On March 6th, Jaime Sunwoo will give a lecture at the Charles B Wang Center at Stony Brook University to discuss the history of SPAM, the canned meat, and its significance in the Asia-Pacific. Sunwoo will investigate SPAM’s popularity in Korea, the Philippines, Okinawa, Guam, and Hawaii from its introduction during World War II and the Korean War. She’ll also share her process creating Specially Processed American Me, and how it inspires conversations about war, colonization, immigration, and class.

Wednesday, March 6th, 4-5pm
Charles B Wang Center
100 Nicolls Rd, Stony Brook, NY 11794
Free and Open to the Public
RSVP at thewangcenter.org

In March, we will share a new scene at Brooklyn Arts Exchange Upstart 2019. In May, we’ll perform a work-in-progress showing produced by Leviathan Lab at The Tank. We’ll provide more details as we approach the date! In the meantime, follow our Facebook and Instagram pages @speciallyprocessed to get a taste of what’s cookin’.

title.rendered: SPAM Brunch with Jaime Sunwoo at Open Space Gallery 10/14

content.rendered:
Join artist Jaime Sunwoo for Sunday brunch at Open Source Gallery. She’ll serve SPAM (and veggie!) fried rice and discuss her project Specially Processed American Me. You’ll learn a bit about SPAM history, her writing and design process, and why she uses SPAM as a metaphor for the Asian American experience. Feel free to bring a SPAM dish to share!

Sunday October 14th 11am
Open Source Gallery
306 17th St, Brooklyn, New York 11215
FREE

Open Source Gallery is an arts-based non-profit organization inspired by the open source movement. In the spirit of this free exchange of knowledge, we provide a forum where art intersects with the community and the world at large. Open Source energizes a diverse and creative community for people of all ages and backgrounds with an emphasis on expression, experimentation, sustainability, and social engagement.

title.rendered: We’re performing at Oye! Avant Garde Night Festival Sept 20-22

content.rendered:
We’re performing a scene from Specially Processed American Me for Oye! Avant Garde Night. You’ll see work from a variety of experimental performers exploring “The Other”. Join us!

Oye! Avant Garde Night at JACK
Presented by OYE GROUP
September 20 – 22 at 8pm
Tickets: $18 in advance, $20 at the door

JACK
505 1/2 Waverly Avenue
Brooklyn, NY 11238

Led by Oye Group Artistic Director & Founder Modesto Flako Jimenez, and curated by Artem Yatsunov, OYE Avant Garde Night! connects emerging artists with community around the critical issues of our day. Now in its fourth year, Oye Group’s annual showcase features radical artists turning up the volume on revolutionary imagination. This year, Cristina Pitter, Jaime Sunwoo, Drew Weinstein, Haleh Roshan, Teddy Tedholm and Animal Engine explore ‘The Other,’ with performances tackling queerness, colorism, body image, immigration, national and cultural identity, military invasions, colonialism and mental wellness.

content.rendered: My grandfather was Japanese-American, and was born in Hawaii. My brother and I started eating Spam as kids whenever we would visit my maternal grandparents. To this day, when I go to visit my obaachan, I request a Japanese Breakfast (eggs, rice, miso soup) and fried Spam.

excerpt.rendered: My grandfather was Japanese-American, and was born in Hawaii. My brother and I started eating Spam as kids whenever we would visit my maternal grandparents. To this day, when I go to visit my obaachan, I request a Japanese Breakfast (eggs, rice, miso soup) and fried Spam.

content.rendered: Growing up Cantonese in Vancouver, I would mostly encounter spam at “cha chan tang”s or Hong Kong cafes/diners especially during breakfast time when they have set meals for a cheap price and one of the options as a part of the meal was spam and instant ramen or macaroni noodle soup. I am curious to know how this noodle soup came to be.. I also don’t remember it ever being called spam on the menu but luncheon meat instead.

content.rendered: I think spam is good.  I like eating it with rice and egg.

excerpt.rendered: I think spam is good.  I like eating it with rice and egg.

content.rendered: My family always kept SPAM in bulk from Costco in the cupboard. We oven baked small slices for sizzling goodness as a banchan (side dish). A bite of SPAM with kimchee and rice is the perfect bite. But mainly it was a must in the kimchi jjigae (kimchee stew) we ate almost weekly, and I thought that’s how it was supposed to be made until I talked with some of my Korean friends. They didn’t like SPAM but  still, nothing beats SPAM in kimchee jjigae for me.

excerpt.rendered: My family always kept SPAM in bulk from Costco in the cupboard. We oven baked small slices for sizzling goodness as a banchan (side dish). A bite of SPAM with kimchee and rice is the perfect bite. But mainly it was a must in the kimchi jjigae (kimchee stew) we ate almost weekly, and I … Continue reading Elleinn →

content.rendered: I am a newcomer to the SPAM world. The first time I cooked it for myself, I was working on the audio design for the upcoming production of Specially Processed American Me and searching for the SPAMmiest sounds I could find, recording all the while. The brilliant crack of the container as it opened The PLOMP on the cutting board as I turned it out The PIPS of the thin slices dropping on the pan, the fervent SIZZ as the pieces released their delicious salty grease And the CRISP of the browned pieces that I snacked on afterward. For the best sounds, slice your SPAM thinly and brown well on both sides until slightly crispy. then, enjoy by itself as a snack or as an accompaniment to a sandwich, scrambled eggs, or anything you can think of! SPAM for all the senses!

excerpt.rendered: I am a newcomer to the SPAM world. The brilliant crack of the container as it opened The … Continue reading Matt Chilton →

content.rendered: I cook SPAM with instant noodle during my college days. It is good with soup based noodle or stir-fried noodles. Both are unhealthy but nostalgic.

excerpt.rendered: I cook SPAM with instant noodle during my college days. It is good with soup based noodle or stir-fried noodles. Both are unhealthy but nostalgic.

content.rendered:
My grandfather went to Europe as a chaplain during World War II and ate nothing but SPAM. After that, it was pretty much banished from the family for generations– until I had the good fortune to stroll into a Hawaiian deli in Lower Manhattan and sample the SPAM Musubi*.

* SPAM Musubi is a popular snack and lunch food in Hawaii composed of a slice of grilled Spam on top of a block of rice, wrapped together with nori in the tradition of Japanese omusubi.

excerpt.rendered: My grandfather went to Europe as a chaplain during World War II and ate nothing but SPAM. After that, it was pretty much banished from the family for generations– until I had the good fortune to stroll into a Hawaiian deli in Lower Manhattan and sample the SPAM Musubi*. * SPAM Musubi is a popular … Continue reading Drew G →

content.rendered: My mom used to pack me SPAM fried rice for lunch when I was in high school. It was so good. I still make it at home. I fry diced SPAM, frozen veggies (a mix of corn, peas, and carrots), onions, and minced garlic in a pan with olive oil. After, I mix in sesame oil, toasted sesame seeds, soy sauce, and black pepper. I usually serve it with a fried egg on top, drizzled with ketchup and sriracha. It’s comforting to eat. And delicious.

title.rendered: Food history and storytelling workshops at Gallery Madison Park (6/24) & Asian American Arts Alliance (7/10)

content.rendered:
Join us for SPAM, War, and Cuisine: A Food History & Storytelling Workshop! Our workshops will take place over a communal SPAM meal, where we’ll discuss SPAM’s history, its legacy in the military, and its influence on cuisine in the Asia-Pacific. Attendees are welcome to share their own SPAM-related stories and recipes.

Free with Suggested Donation.

Upcoming Workshops:
Sunday 6/24 2pm at Gallery Madison Park (45 East 34th Street, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10016)
Tuesday 7/10 7pm at Asian American Arts Alliance (20 Jay St, #740, Brooklyn, NY 11201)

This is a capped event, so please reserve a spot if you’d like to join us: RSVP on Eventbrite.
